positive.review:
[u][b]-Quick Review-[/b][/u]
Star Wars: The Old Republic is an MMORPG developed by BioWare and later handed off to Broadsword Online Games. You’ll create a character for the Old Galactic Republic or Sith Empire, level up, collect gear, vanity pets and mounts, complete quests, get achievements, collect decorations and buy houses, level up more, and run around on numerous planets from the Star Wars franchise. The biggest standout features in The Old Republic are the Class Related Quests, and the incredible amount of voiced dialogue in the game. I played for around 350 hours as a Free to Play Account before deciding to chip in $15 for a subscription for a month, and to unlock more character slots, and see the rest of the content.
After my account relapsed into “Preferred status” (Free to play: Never bought anything. Preferred: Has more perks, but back to FTP restrictions), I finished playing as all the different classes and chipped away at achievements casually. I may resubscribe occasionally for future content, but one subscription was enough for me for now. (If I do resubscribe again I’ll have saved up lots of credits and know exactly what premium stuff I want before my subscription ends again, stuff like housing upgrades requiring over 1 mil credits, or buying stuff in general costing over 1 mil credits.)

[u][b]Review Video:[/b][/u]
Hey hold on! before you keep reading, how about watching a 46 minute video I made instead? If you don't like reading, or are curious about watching gameplay please watch my:
https://youtu.be/4-SEahWatcU

[u][b]-Detailed breakdown review-[/b][/u]
[b]Story:[/b] In general sweeping terms, you’re playing as a character for the Empire or Republic, who is part of a 3 Act Structure, usually the first act is about some kind of growth or a hunt or something, then the second act is an in-between character development series for you and your crew, and lastly act 3 ends on Correllia (Probably the worst planet to navigate in the game, to think the YT-1300, YT-2000, and YT-2400 light freighters were made here. No wonder everyone wants to leave the darn planet, it’s a cartography-deathtrap).
After you’ve, become the Hero of the Republic/Empire, Ultimate Bounty Hunter / Agent, Jedi Master, Sith Lord, whatever your “final form” might be at the end of Act 3, you can continue your journey with the expansions which came out! Even as a Free to Play Account, you can access a few of the expansions: Rise of the Hutt Cartel, Galactic Starfighter, Galactic Strongholds, and lastly Shadow of Revan.
With the expansions, there will be some call-backs to your past deeds, for example as a Bounty Hunter, on the planet Rishi (the Shadow of Revan Expansion) there was reference to my status as “Grand Champion of the Great Hunt”. And all the way to the Legacy of the Sith Expansion, my status as a Mandalorian is acknowledged and kinship with Torrian being particularly special.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3369767723

[b]Gameplay:[/b] You know how most MMORPG’s control, right? Movement with WASD on the keyboard, looking around with the mouse, abilities and skills bound to 1-9 on the keyboard or click ‘em on the action bar with your mouse, get experience for killing stuff and completing quests, level up to get stronger new abilities, and as you reach higher levels equip gear to give you beneficial stats to increase your damage and health pool. [i](Most people are familiar with MMO concepts, if you’re not feel free to let me know and I’ll write it out or send ‘ya a link to a beginners video or something)[/i]
Star Wars: The Old Republic has all the typical expected MMORPG things with a Star Wars coat of paint over the top. Level up via questing, dungeons, or grinding exp out some other way. At Max level after you’ve finished the content you work at getting the best gear with the best stats. Once I reached that point, I marked The Old Republic as complete, I was in a raiding guild a lifetime ago on World of Warcraft and I won’t go back to that life in any game… and once I reach that point in any MMO it’s time for me to bow out. [i](I’m not going to log on and play a video game like it’s my job… unless you want to pay me how much I earn for working, I’ll do it then! DM me your best offers. lol)[/i]
However, the journey to get to that point was enjoyable and I’m satisfied with my experience playing The Old Republic! You have 8 Classes in total, but they mirror each other so, for the Republic you have “Jedi Knight” which plays the same as the “Sith Warrior” on the Empire side… the remaining classes are: Jedi Consular / Sith Inquisitor, Republic Trooper / Imperial Agent, Smugger / Bounty Hunter. Each Class also has its own Starship, and group of companions who join you for the adventure!
At character creation you choose your faction, be it Republic or Imperial, then choose and customize your species ranging from Human, Cyborg, and Zabrak… then they get ya as a FTP account because you can’t play as Twi’lek, Miraluka, Chiss, Sith Pureblood, etc unless you subscribe.
After Character creation, the fun begins! I suggest you sit back and enjoy the ride, don’t worry when the game announces “Exp reduced, subscribe for more perks!”. I think you should play a character through all the free content and then decide at that point if you want to subscribe to increase the level cap and get the rest of the expansions.
Again, after playing my Bounty Hunter to level 60 and finishing the available expansions, completing the Sith Warrior, Imperial Agent, and Jedi Consular personal stories, I played roughly 350 hours in game. You could quit there, but I enjoyed the game enough to cough up the subscription for a month to unlock more character slots and the expansions.
 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3392427542

[b]Conclusion:[/b] Star Wars: The Old Republic has been an adventure. I haven’t been hooked by an MMORPG like this for a long time, and it’s primarily because of the subscription model and coupled with it being a Star Wars Game.
Again, I would encourage anyone interested in the game to give it a try, the Free To Play Model is very generous, if you play smart you can make it so your first (and possibly ONLY) time subscribing will get you tons of great upgrades and unlocked content.
But it IS an MMORPG… so expect to spend a lot of time playing, expect to stick around… don’t rush the adventure, sit back, and let your choices guide your characters down their path… be that light side paths, dark side paths… or somewhere in between.

Star Wars: The Old Republic (SWTOR) remains one of the most ambitious MMORPGs ever made, blending traditional MMO gameplay with the narrative depth of a single-player Bioware RPG. Set thousands of years before the Skywalker saga, it offers eight unique class storylines that immerse players in the moral complexity and mythos of the Star Wars universe. Two of the standout experiences—the Smuggler and the Sith Warrior—represent the light and dark extremes of personal ambition, charisma, and power, each offering vastly different tones and gameplay experiences while sharing Bioware’s signature storytelling flair.

Leveling in The Old Republic has evolved beautifully over the years, transitioning from a traditional MMO grind into a streamlined, story-driven experience. Players can now progress almost entirely through their class storylines and planet arcs without feeling under-leveled or forced into repetitive side quests. Each planet feels distinct, with its own tone and flavor—Nar Shaddaa’s neon skylines evoke criminal chaos, while Alderaan’s regal landscapes teem with political tension. The companions you recruit along the way deepen both the narrative and gameplay loop, offering personal stories, combat assistance, and a genuine sense of camaraderie that keeps the journey engaging from level one to the level cap.

Combat, meanwhile, balances accessibility with satisfying depth. Every class features distinct abilities that blend traditional MMO cooldown management with cinematic flair. The Smuggler’s cover mechanics and dual blasters make every firefight feel like a shootout straight from the Mos Eisley Cantina, while the Sith Warrior’s lightsaber combat channels raw aggression and elegance, leaping into the fray with devastating precision. Endgame options—operations, flashpoints, PvP arenas, and galactic starfighter battles—ensure there’s plenty to do once the main story concludes. Whether you play solo or with a group, The Old Republic maintains a strong sense of identity in its combat rhythm, bridging classic MMO structure with the pulpy, action-packed heart of Star Wars.

Graphically, The Old Republic shows its age but compensates with strong art direction and atmosphere. The stylized visuals, somewhere between The Clone Wars and Knights of the Old Republic, have aged gracefully, especially in modern resolutions. Environments remain impressively diverse, from the frozen wastelands of Hoth to the molten industrial hellscape of Corellia. The real star, however, is the game’s sound design. Blaster fire cracks with authenticity, lightsabers hum with menace, and the sweeping orchestral score channels the spirit of John Williams without feeling derivative. Combined with full voice acting for every quest—a monumental feat for an MMO—these elements make The Old Republic a truly cinematic experience that continues to hold its own more than a decade after release.
It's enjoyable, and was fun. Just a bit outdated by now, however there's still people out there playing it and worth a shot if you get time.
Great Game, honestly just needs more main content to keep it going and it'd be well worth it for the subscription.
one of the best star wars games i played... don't mind the playtime i played before i ever got steam.

Despite the predatory monetary practices this is the chillest MMO I've played solo. I've bounced between a couple of them, playing for a month then not touching it for at least 6 (FFXIV, WOW, ESO, etc). If you just wanna play a good RPG with 8 unique stories with choices to make, this is the MMO for you. It's got that Bioware charm that I love so much.

Hasn't killed World of Warcraft in 2011 as people wanted it too but stayed alive unlike other MMORPG's.

With that it did definitly better than New World. 

It definitly is okay as an mmorpg, but feels more than a single player bioware title ( wich is totally fine) but sometimes it feels like the Game has a  idendity crisis.
And this would may be a critique... but the Story is damn good.
Игра крутая, жалко только что нельзя присоединиться к мятежу Дарта Малгуса.

The ultimate online Star Wars experience for RPG gameplay, lore and community.

I've been playing since launch both separately and now as part of Steam. This is a must for any fan who wants to expand their SW gaming either single player, multiplayer or as a combination of both... you decide. The game has changed since launch, some areas simplified others expanded, but the feel of the game has continued unabated. I recommend subscribing for a more in-depth experience with all features available but you can easily try it free-to-play (F2P) and sub later. 

I play with family members and friends I have known in game for years. I have created characters for different types of play styles; from single player adventurers and explorers to multiplayer specialists, to material gathering and crafting-focused individuals. I have spent hours in great seasonal events, spontaneous fan generated games, contests, giveaways, lore discussions, guild parties and more. It is friendly to both those new to MMO style gaming and veterans of the genre.

Note: When subscribing, adding cartel coins, etc. I [b]strongly recommend[/b] going through the main SW:TOR website rather than doing it through Steam, as it can be buggy.

May the Force be with you... always.
It's has a great, unique narrative for each player. has a good combat system and the dilague is peak

This is my first MMORPG video game & I must say, I am exceptionally impressed, especially with the storyline. Gameplay is smooth and really cool too. SWTOR holds its ground really well for a game that came out 14 yeara ago! And I respect the devs for keeping the game around with updates. They made a masterpiece. As a star wars nerd, I'm glad I came across SWTOR and 20+ hours in, I'm enjoying it to the fullest.
Fun for me, played with a few friends and if you like a Star Wars themed WOW this will scratch that itch. story ain't half bad either.

its a realy good game i just wish the game had all the better stuff from before disney bot the franchise ( im talking about all the customizing for companions). for new players this is great but for the old players this went from 5 of 5 to 4 of 5.

One of the best Star Wars games ever made. Great value for money for new players. There is so much content to explore in the F2P model. Strongly recommend to pay for subscription or cosmetics at some point if you like the game, to support the devs. 8 different origins stories to start with, and a dedicated community that will hopefully keep the game running for many years to come.

Amazing story, fun combat, pretty good monetization system / value.  If you buy a single month of sub you get (almost) all of the benefits of subs and every single expansion currently released forever.  The only thing I think you lose if you aren't actively subbed is any new sub rewards and the monthly cartel coins, plus you don't get any new xpacs until you resub.

Ahh SWTOR... I want to like you more than I do. 
When it comes to this game, I have three recommendations. 

1. Once you finish your character quest (and possibly one run of the galactic war) don't bother playing the story onwards. You WILL be roped in as 'The Super Special Awesome Chosen One', you WILL be forced to lead a resistance (even if you don't want to) and you WILL be given the most dogshit companions that make you wish more games let you shoot them dead mid cutscene like in Rogue Trader. 

2. See the cartel store? Don't. Yes, the skins are pretty, I've done it too, I'm not perfect. But the more we buy from there, the less the devs bother to add ANY NEW CONTENT besides "Ooh look it's the outfit from Andor! You like Andor, you liiiiiike Star Wars, buy the slop!" 

3. Play the Flashpoints. Genuinely, some of the most fun this game has. Small, predominantly self-contained little dungeons that give good gear, good interactions, and the best bossfights. Just be aware some of those bosses demand you to deal with some outright silly mechanics.

The best action-packed and immersive sw game ever!!!!!!
and the twileks, those darn tootin twileks
Very amazing game. I started in 2011 and every year I play it because of it's immersive world.
If you wanna play a fun mmo this is it, if you love star wars this will put you on a good story for 8 different characters you can play through its fun and takes time but its well spent.

Still the best Star Wars MMORPG out there!
The plot quality varies, but most classes storylines are worth playing through, and the voice acting is still good after all these years.
If you play at the right times, you shouldn't have any trouble finding players for group content.
Recommended!
Favourite star wars game of all time - loved the stories, the customisation and the open world aspects. Please keep this game going! Big love XD

good game, could use less pay to play content though, a lot of nice or just expected things are locked behind a paywall, i understand the devs needing to keep the money coming, but when playing a stars wars game like this, i expect fair freedom on both side, paying should be a way to cheat your way through an obstacle, instead what i'd consider to be half of the options (when making characters and saving them, some items, the end of the campaign, max lv, ...), are locked behind a subscription
Amazing stories, fun gameplay, really recommend finding a few mates to play this with, the flashpoints are great. 10/10 recommend for a Star Wars roleplay experience!

Good game, wish they hadn't removed a lot of the features they used to have. Planetary and factional reputation, companion specialization, a working group auto-loop implementation, the ability to finish Heroics via conversation with the quest giver - they've put a lot of work into this game, it's a shame to see parts being thrown away in the interest of simplification.
After all of these years, still an awesome game.  If you love old-school BioWare games, deep story, and Star Wars (of course), this is the game for you

It is a fun game where you can kinda have free range to do all ya like. The stories are well written , and the older content is easier to breeze through, even if the population is not as big as it once was, it is a fun game to kill an afternoon. Makes ya see good and evil is not just empire and republic .
Even after all these years, this game still holds up. I am excited for the new adventures and can't wait to hop back in!
after years of playing this game its still always great to come back one of the best mmo's ive played always a great time
Game still looks choppy but besides that .. FOR THE SITH!
Very reasonable game for free to play, I've enjoyed the story and scenery of SWTOR very at the core of how Star Wars should feel. 9/10 recommend!
Good and not addicting in the slightest...Just need a little more every day.

One of the my fave MMO's of all time only bested by WOW. It may say 4 hours on my account but i've played this game through the swtor launcher since day one of release. Every Class is fun and has it's own cool story arcs like any other rpg. Where this game thrives is letting you live in and breath the air of this galaxy far far away in the closet experience you may ever get. 10/10

most unserious serious game of all time; not many games have you searching for an entire platoon of soldiers, just to find out they were all experimented on and turned into droids. you find this out from the last survivor left, who's slowly losing his free will as the droid's program overtakes his consciousness. and at the end of this, the soldier asks you to end his suffering, and you have the option to kill him, or leave him alive... and then i blink and i'm talking to this alderaan "noble" who is being RACIST to me AND making my job more difficult (mainly by just acting like The Worst Guy You Know) and then i have the option to punch him in the face

the galaxy is just such a big place and it's full of so many possibilities

I play from time to time, always come back. This game is so good that I literally bought a PC to play it when I first discovered it in 2016. It scratches a Star Wars game itch that new games aren't doing.
Essential game for Star Wars fans. ESPECIALLY fans of Knights of the Old Republic games
Plenty of content. Worth the price for the vast storyline/content alone.  Definitely recommend giving it a try.

The game’s graphics might look a little dated by today’s standards, but then again it’s a game that released back in 2011, the games eight stories are actually fantastic and you could really immerse yourself into the lore and story to carve out your own Star Wars adventure.
Lots of gameplay, fun with friends or by yourself. The story is immersive with plenty of different choices affecting how you play.

Star Wars: The Old Republic stands out as one of the most engaging MMO experiences for anyone who loves deep storytelling. Each class features its own fully developed narrative, giving you real agency and making every playthrough feel personal. Whether you choose to be a ruthless Sith, a disciplined Jedi, or a chaotic Smuggler, the writing keeps you invested from the start.

Combat is classic MMO-style but smooth and satisfying. The game’s worldbuilding is where it truly shines: iconic planets, strong visual design, and a soundtrack that nails the Star Wars vibe.

Even after years, SWTOR remains a solid, content-rich MMO with a dedicated community. If you're into narrative-driven games or just want to live out your own Star Wars fantasy, this one is absolutely worth your time.

i LOVE the role pay and power fantasy of this game. the gameplay is also pretty solid, it just falls short on
being almost entirely subscription focused. can you play without it sure. but you are going to struggle tl;dr
8/10
this game is probably the most immersive sw game weve got rn i love it tho i know its not for everyone but i think my time spent kinda speaks for itself \_('-')_/
Great game, very nice class story with 100h of gameplay,
Love the game and the whole Star Wars franchise. I recommend the game.
mange bra historier till ver klasse ardige racer å videre bare in game purches når det er for våpen å clær er lit skjedelig

Good classic style MMO experience with top tier era Bioware stories. A story driven MMO with a clear endgame path and great encouragement for multiple alternative characters. 

A subscription does improve overall experience a ton.
Great game with fun stories and classes. Doesn't require a subscription and if you have the in game currency you can use it to buy your friends stuff if they don't have any which is nice.

Great Star Wars game set in the time of the old republic. It takes a bit to get used to the gameplay but there is so many stories and routes you can take throughout the game. My favorite is the Imperial Agent as there are so many different paths you can take to dramatically change the story. Overall its a very good game.
lots of fun without subscription, amazing as a solo player

This game is a lot of fun, however the subscription cost to play ongoing is rather high, and you cannot go to deep into the game without the subscription.  The game play is highly interactive, while the story is set, you choose how dark or light your character is going to be, and those choices do have some mild inpact on the overal story.
Fantastic game that’s even better with friends. I return every few years to the story, and it never disappoints.

One of my favourite games ever, despite being an MMO, you can easily play it single player through all stories and DLCs. 

Worth playing for the story alone.

Despite the early controversies this game has faced, the lack of recent story content and the age of the game, it still holds up as a fantastic Star wars experience, with *free, fully voiced* class stories and a nuanced Empire v Republic narrative. I really enjoy the voice acting performances, particularly in the Smuggler story.

[h1]SWTOR: The Living Legend[/h1]
Star Wars: The Old Republic is a good MMORPG that reminds me of WoW, by which it was inspired.
First things first..
[h2]STORY[/h2]
There are a lot of different storylines for both factions(Republic and The Empire) and different classes. Each class has a different story depending on faction. You will spend quite a lot of time completing them all, but if you're F2P you will not manage to do that, i will say why later.
The quality of these storylines is rather mid for me. Some are interesting, some are boring. Im sure you will find some of them to your liking.
But there's not only class stories. There are also a lot of DLC's that tell their own story.
To be short: there is enough of story content, no need to worry about that.

And now, the most interesting part..
[h2]GAMEPLAY[/h2]
I suggest you look at the release date of the game. Once you know it, you can be sure that the battle gameplay is right from that time. It's not cool in 2025, it's not interesting. It's almost the same WoW in this part. But i must say..it looks good.
 But everything good ends someday..
Money. That's what devs love the most. They want you to take your money out of your wallet and pay. Pay for subscription to unlock all the DLC and actually enjoy the game. Pay for species that can be your character.
Their beloved subscription also allows you to have more than 4 characters on one server.
Yes. that's why i said that you will not be able to experience all the storylines if you are F2P. There is more stories than 4. In short... 
[h3]PAY!!![/h3]
And if you not - get a lot of limitations. Even the privileged players(that paid for sub once) have them. Not all of them though. But the LIMIT OF CREDITS(local currency) is still 1 million like for F2P.
There is a hyperinflation in the game and some items on the local market(GTN) cost a lot more than 1m. But devs don't give a f@@@ about that. Go stretch your wallet to play the game normally. 
As you see, it's the most frustrating part of the game.
[h2]CONCLUSION[/h2]
It's not a bad game. It's definitely worth trying, but if you want to experience the game fully - at some point, you will have to pay.
As you see, it has a lot of pros and cons. So go and check it out, if you want.
Good game for free, narratives are good but the graphics style is on the older side.
Timesink, but a decent one. This is one of the few MMOs that's actually not so bad to play without a monthly subscription.
I love this game, it is so excellent! such a fun experience, hundreds of hours of gameplay, super fun characters and missions! I highly recommend!

I have enjoyed this game off and on for years. Even if you're not an MMO fan it is worth playing through the stories. It is very accessible for solo players looking for a star wars rpg with near endless hours of content. If you enjoy the free play experience you should sub for at least a month to get a fuller experience.
This game has every aspect that a MMORPG for Star Wars that someone could want. The Story lines for each class are unique and are some of the best story lines ive ever played through.

I have gotten so much out of this game and barley touched the multiplayer aspect of the game. 
Maybe one day I should do that?

I personally like this game because off it's story and also the class based system.

Sure the game is outdated but I would still give it an 8/10
Very surprised by this game, story is amazing, so far so good. Hopefully the endgame is equally nice. My only problem... the graphics, game looks extremely dated compared to games like WoW, GW2 etc.

swtor is game for people love star wars and likes mmorpgs and doesn't mind the grind for gear and levels and also enjoys the the story and the lore of the game, even with its dlcs. i would reccomend the game to anyone who enjoys star wars at all.
Quick, play it before someone realizes this still exists and they sunset it.

Immerse yourself in the Star Wars universe! Become a jedi, sith, smuggler, or other iconic roles that you've seen in the movies. The devs are still expanding this game after 12 years, and it's amazing! Fully enjoyable solo, it's even better if you get involved in a guild and can take on the more difficult content.

I've played this game since at least 2014 with Rise of the Hutt Cartel, and I'm glad it's still around. It's good to see Broadsword has taken over development for the game while BioWare... does whatever they're doing.
It is nostalgic and very enjoyable. I am glad the servers are still running.

This is a good game.
Although the graphics look a bit dated now, they still hold up enough to not look bad while playing.
The story grips you more than enough to not care too much about the graphics anyway.

Free-to-play players get access to all the main story arcs and the game is worth playing just for those.
With that said, it's definitely a better experience when some cash is invested, be it a small amount to unlock a number 
of decent (although usually standard) features such as personal cargo (AKA "bank").

You can play on either side (Republic vs Imperial / good vs bad / light vs dark) and you can decide light or dark you want your character to actually be.
You can play as many different types (class) of characters from jedi/sith to bounty hunters and soldiers, each with their own story (you can actually play as one class while playing another's storyline!)

There's plenty of things to do, a massive galaxy of worlds to explore at your leisure and that is only improved by subscribing, having access to extra (above free-to-play) features such as higher level cap, extra story arcs and some limitations are lifted.

The character creation is fine. Plenty of options are available. To get the really fancy looking stuff, you'll need to spend real money though.

If you haven't already, try it; it's free! You can always upgrade to some form of payment if you think it's worth it...

May the force be with you.
Great game! Even 14 years later the game is still getting game enhancing updates.

This has been one of my true comfort games for years. I’ve been here since launch, and no matter what else I’m playing, I always find myself coming back to it. It’s fun, rich with story, and just feels like home in a way few games do. I’ll always recommend it.
Very solid and expansive star wars experience, lots of game to be played.
I enjoyed SWTOR for its atmosphere and cinematic storytelling, but it didn’t convince me to spend money. The storylines eventually felt repetitive, and the game lost its sense of freshness over time.
It's not KOTOR, but the gameplay is still addictive

best MMO ever, tho i have to say i wish they didn't push the same plot eventually for all characters instead offering side missions after completing the main story, only Barsenthor and Darth Nox should be the ones to eventually become the commander and defeat Tenebrae, the side content is amazing, it's not necessary for all characters to become the commander (at least that's my opinion)

Fantastic game to play with a very immersive story that explores the galaxy far far away in new ways 
so much content over the years and even though the micro-transactions do get annoying when it's supposed to be a free to play game at least you can earn a lot of the important stuff via long hours of grinding 
but the gameplay is good and it is definitely a fun time to wander the worlds with friends

While I still wish we could get a standalone continuation of KotOR 1 and KotOR 2, SWTOR remains the closest spiritual successor. Its timeless visual style, years of dedicated support, fantastic soundtrack, and the sheer number of story arcs to experience make it truly special. Keep it up, devs and players alike.
Even as someone who joined into the game so many years of its release, its sm fun. Really goes to show how Star Wars games have always been amazing.

SWTOR; A game about eight different playable characters and a whole galaxy of NPC:s bullying a 70-year-old goth/emo man with asthma and a breathing apparatus. 10/10, would recommend. 
(leave my boi Malgus alone)
Coming back to this game and still loving it. Shooting lighting still so much fun and now i can do that as a Jedi.
For those o love STAR WARS and like mmorpg games, this game is very good.

I do not and have never cared about or even seen a Star Wars movie. Personally I don't care much for the MMO aspect of this game. The RPG side of this game is a completely different story. The class stories in this game are fantastic. The dialogue options feel like they impact the game in a meaningful way and allows for a lot of creativity.

If you love Star Wars, then this game is a must play. 

The MMO aspect of the game can be lacking and the combat can feel clunky at times, but the fact that you can play solo and enjoy the main aspects of the game (story, RPG elements, open world) without much of a barrier, is enough to highly recommend this title. And who knows, maybe after expiriencing the  game and its mechanics for yourself, you might enjoy the MMO aspect and the combat as well.

So go into this game with the idea that it is a story driven RPG Star Wars game and you will have a blast. What happens after will depend.

As long as you steer clear of the awful community, the absolute cesspool that is SWTOR gen chat, and the drama that are the guilds whom worship their discordian overlords far too much to function within society, this game comes highly recommended.
i love it it has dialog options great levels and tons of extra stuff to explore 5 stars would reccomond

Its a classic massive multiplayer game, honestly awesome for free. Star wars roblox essentially. Theres features I would for sure add regarding the pets and buying armour or weapons early in the game is essentially useless, wish someone told me that lmao. Save up your credits for the DLC portion of the game/when you first get a base after completing enough of the story mode.

I'm a Star Wars Galaxies MMO fan myself, this one is nice for chasing stories, it's an easier game style, you get levels instead of building up Professions.  Different pace, feels familiar, less intense than the random mobs that can kill you in Star Wars Galaxies, where a mob of pixie butterflies could become your demise. :)

I liked it, worth a playthrough or two using diff classes for diff story lines.  Easy to level up characters, a lot less grind and just an easy flow if all you have is an itch for anything Star Wars, this scratch will suffice.  If you're already heavily a Star Wars Galaxies nerd, this will suffice for a short while but that Itch from Star Wars Galaxies is more like Crack-Cocaine and only more Crack-Cocaine can fill the spot! :)

Welp, I'm off to save the Galaxy...again!  ^_^

Very fun game, much to do, you fell progression, does empty your wallet if you don't want to have a free to play account. I reccomend this to be one of the games where you have many hours, otherwise, it just isn't as fun or worth spending money on. I reccomend subscribing for a month before permanently accessing more content as well.

As someone who has been playing WoW for 16 years, I have tried way too many other games looking for a similar thrill, only to abandon them 2 days after.
Not SWTOR though. I am enjoying it a lot and I can see myself picking it up whenever I am bored with WoW. Great pace, rich story, light vs dark options that actually matter, tons to discover in the world and to learn about your own class/character, and the ability to play solo if you prefer, have various strongholds and unlocking multiple expansions just by subbing once. There is tons to love about this game!
The only thing I don't love so far is the lack of any in-game guidance outside of tutorials (e.g. the lack of simple vendor markers that forces you to either google where the vendor is located every time you need it, or just run around in-game like a headless chicken trying to find it. Nevertheless, I give it a solid 8.5/10.
great value for a free to play game. Voice acting is very good and characters are interesting.
One of the greatest star wars works in any form if you love the star wars universe  this is a game for you
You get to role play a Jedi, Enough said. For real though amazing dialogue and story line. Fun game play. You can literally use the force. I love it! Very well made game.

this game could be realted to gundam :d
/bow 
stiletto trap

curved dagger 
assassin's strike
It has a really good mix of fantasy, sci-fi with some elements of mythology for historical context. An offerers good amount of storylines for diverse character fields

Although there are things that could be improved, as such with many mmos, I really do enjoy the fact that your character's choices and story matter. It's enjoyable to be able to build connections with your companions.

The other thing I enjoy is that it is separate from the main storyline as we are so far in the past. This allows for the republic and the empire to have different "faces" and we can experience what they were like at their peaks.

Its free to play but it doesn't have predatory monetisation practices. All main content is Accessible by F2P players with only some end game extra content being locked for subscribers (as far as I can tell at the moment, I'm only level 30)

Plenty of people but you dont need groups for the first few areas of the game because they make sure you are pretty powerful (standard thing for F2P MMOs that have been around for awhile, its to help you get through the beginning quicker) but you can still die if you are not paying attention.

Its got all the star wars charm, including funny and cheesy dialogue, good characters and alien speech that literally sounds like someone talking in "caveman speech"

I think its a lot of fun and I would recommend this. You don't need to treat this game like a 2nd job.
Easily my favorite MMO. Great stories and a good time for casuals and hardcore players alike.

#1: DO NOT be fooled by the fact that this is an MMORPG! It is, in fact, a BioWare RPG game, one of the last good BioWare RPGs. If you remember the original Mass Effect and Dragon Age games for their stories and characters, you can still experience some of that classic BioWare writing in this game. Each character class has its own unique full storyline through the base game along with the faction storylines on each planet, and its own unique companions that go with them into the expansion content - all of which can be completed solo with no problems at all, though you will need to still be online to access the game servers. It does use typical tab targeting ability hotbar MMORPG gameplay mechanics so you do have to deal with that, but if it's not a problem then I would say the story is worth it.

Speaking of the expansion content, that's where another very cool thing about this game comes into play: the pricing. The base game which includes the original story for all player classes is free, but if you play through all of that and decide it was fun and you want more, just paying for a $15 1 month subscription a single time will grant you permanent access to all the expansions, and if during the subscription period you make a character of a subscriber-only race, you can continue playing them after the sub expires and unlock the species permanently by getting that character to level 50.

I'm not a very social MMO player, so I can't speak in detail to the quality of the PvP, raids, and overall multiplayer experience, but the game is very active to this day with strong RP communities as well. I recommend this game to everyone.

The only game I felt like I belonged in, or actually lived in, was a universe where I really thought I was part of it. I recommend this game to anyone who wants to escape from reality and loves Star Wars.
great fun, lots to do, and very solo friendly.
For Star Wars fans, it is a must have.  It gives a whole different side to the story-line within the Star Wars universe.
As a new Player its  chaos at the Start after a while ppl helped me now im the Master and teach ppl i recomend not installing this game unless your mental

negative.review:
This game has what, around 240 hours of unique class story content that's all fully voiced? I can hardly think of any SP game that tackles this kind of ambition. I think it's incredible.

This game has the potential to be among my favorites, but it just completely butchers the gameplay and balance for someone who mostly plays SP games and want just a modicum of intended challenge. Instead, you have to artificially restrict yourself for this to happen, which I just dislike.

If they ever patch in a hard mode or a difficulty scaling system that can actually present some challenge in the way you play and build your character, I can see myself coming back to it just to enjoy all the different class stories, like a true Star Wars Singleplayer game.

could of been the goat mmo if the right people drove results on it, instead of underachieving shitty customer service  shitty otp hostaging  (recieve 30+ mins later)   director ego going at it. 

Graphics are  just off. graphics for swtor should of been a thing they fixed early on release yet    decades later~ still seems likea  2bit hack on the graphix and gameplay is choppy at best. 

crafting system was half assed 
ah but no price checker built in again half assed. 

theme of swtor to me is coulda been great but again half assed.

Up until the conclusion of the base game (prior to the Rise of the Hutt Cartel expansion), this game is outstanding. Each class has a very engaging and enjoyable personalised storyline that allows you to live your respective Star Wars character fantasy, with tons of old-school Bioware charm. Every quest-giver was a cutscene where you could engage in dialogue and define your character's mentality or attitude! I lost countless hours to this game and it's strong stance on putting narrative first, even moreso than most conventional MMORPGs tend to do.

However, it feels like they were victims of their own success - the model was unsustainable. They couldn't continue intricately crafted and personalised content for each of the classes with each expansion as it developed; it was simply too much work to keep up. So things started becoming 'shared' experiences, where a character (regardless of class) would go through the same main plotline as all the other classes, and you'd have barely any recognition of your previous efforts (because to do so would require personalisation of the content, which they can no longer do without drastically extending the development time between updates).

This ideology of making the universe at large a singular, quasi-linear experience for all characters persists to this day. As much as I enjoyed the game prior to the first expansion, once the Eternal Empire expansions came out and they established a time-jump along with scattering all the class-exclusive companions to the four winds for any character to encounter, I felt like whatever spark had drawn me in had been lost. My character didn't feel unique, with unique adventures, experiences or choices - I was on the same journey as everyone else.

It's still a fine game, and what made it so special in the beginning still remains. You can still play each of the unique class storylines until they converge - you can even change what class you are mechanically in order to experience a different classes' narrative through a system called Combat Styles (essentially: 'I want to play a character with Sith Inquisitor abilities, but check out the Sith Warrior class storyline/companions') which is really cool! They've also introduced the means to customise your companions to be any role, so previously DPS-exclusive companions can now be Tanks, or Healers. It encourages you to bring the companion you like the most, or the one who's narrative you want to explore at that time, without giving up any synergy with your own character's chosen playstyle. All in all, a fantastic game if you're a Star Wars or KOTOR fan all the same - just go into post Act-3 content with the proper expectations.

Oh - and when it went Free to Play, EA nickel-and-dimed it to death with a massive amount of focus on squeezing money out of everything, with things as simple as the ability to hide your head slot item being put behind a paywall. Incredibly egregious and greedy. As the game has transitioned to being put on maintenance mode this mentality has eased up *a little* (presumably to attract more players who don't wish to pay actual money to play) but between that and the Cartel Store pushing every kind of feature/race unlock/cosmetic under the sun exclusively for premium currency it really does feel like they've stripped the F2P model of all it's flesh and are selling it back to you by the pound. Urgh.

Nostalgia aside, I have to give the game a thumbs down because I remembered who owns EA now. And all the monetisation, obviously, but mostly the first thing.

Don't get me wrong, the game as a whole is probably fine.  However there are several things this game does that I find ridiculously annoying.  

1.  The level scaling...IMO one of the best things about mmorpg's is grinding levels to get more powerful.  That is irrelevant here.  You get a ton of xp boosts for free...yeah i get it everyone wants to get to the endgame content faster.  I have never really been able to run around as my true level because the game scales it down.  Essentially the only thing leveling up does is unlock new skills.

2.  The crafting at its base is also probably fine, however, as a ftp or even preferred status just feels like a kick to the face.  You need 1 crafting and 2 gathering professions to make items unless you buy the missing items from the auction house.  F2p and preferred players only get to pick 2 while you need 3. 

3.  Preferred player status gets thrown around on the website like its the holy grail.  Preferred status doesnt do anything for me really,  unlocked expansions from years ago when i first tried the game and still havent made it far enough to reach the first expansion.  

I just cant in good conscience recommend this game for anyone.  I wish years ago i never spent money so i could be a subscriber.  coming back it just feels like a handicap and i cant play a game with handicap coded into the game.

This game has what, around 240 hours of unique class story content that's all fully voiced? I can hardly think of any SP game that tackles this kind of ambition. I think it's incredible.

This game has the potential to be among my favorites, but it just completely butchers the gameplay and balance for someone who mostly plays SP games and want just a modicum of intended challenge. Instead, you have to artificially restrict yourself for this to happen, which I just dislike.

If they ever patch in a hard mode or a difficulty scaling system that can actually present some challenge in the way you play and build your character, I can see myself coming back to it just to enjoy all the different class stories, like a true Star Wars Singleplayer game.

I lost hours to trouble shooting the steam version and would not recommend using the steam port to any of my fellow star wars lovers. This game and the content is good. If you have never played it, then it is well worth it. Even to sub for just 1 month or 2 months as it has so much to offer. Most of the 8 class stories are simply amazing and could be full fledged games if fleshed out a little more.

However, the game has not had any new content for years and is just in a state of maintenance with what I suspect equipped with a skeleton crew. Date missions which are about 5 minutes long, or more stuff for the ludicrously priced Real Money Shop including dyes are not content. Why on earth do we have to pay to change the color of our armor. The whole Cartel Market is incredibly outdated and is the only form of continued development the game now receives. I could go into more predatory practices like the 1 mil credit cap for free to play players (anyone who isnt subbed) and how that buys you ABSOLUTELY nothing in the in game auction house (Galactic Trade Market GTN). 

The game at its core is absolutely phenomenal, and if you only sub for 1 month you keep all the content up to that point. But there is no new content, there hasnt been for years. The game in its current state has been completely abandoned and is left on life support. Bye
Although the game is very old and could do with a update, it's still a great game. However this is the greediest store page I have seen, items are way over priced.

For the time that I was able to play the game I had fun with it. That was when I could log in. 

Customer support won't respond to you when you ask for help when attempting to log in. Their partner EA won't respond either. Don't bother asking for anything via Email. Any code they give you won't be correct code that you need so you then have to ask for another email which takes up to 15 minutes. That I am fine with, its when it takes longer than that for the email to arrive and for the codes to simply log in to the game still be wrong. Resorting in a never ending cycle of bad communication and non-communication. 

Great game, bad customer support. If your able to play then have fun but don't expect to get any help when you need it.

Up until the conclusion of the base game (prior to the Rise of the Hutt Cartel expansion), this game is outstanding. Each class has a very engaging and enjoyable personalised storyline that allows you to live your respective Star Wars character fantasy, with tons of old-school Bioware charm. Every quest-giver was a cutscene where you could engage in dialogue and define your character's mentality or attitude! I lost countless hours to this game and it's strong stance on putting narrative first, even moreso than most conventional MMORPGs tend to do.

However, it feels like they were victims of their own success - the model was unsustainable. They couldn't continue intricately crafted and personalised content for each of the classes with each expansion as it developed; it was simply too much work to keep up. So things started becoming 'shared' experiences, where a character (regardless of class) would go through the same main plotline as all the other classes, and you'd have barely any recognition of your previous efforts (because to do so would require personalisation of the content, which they can no longer do without drastically extending the development time between updates).

This ideology of making the universe at large a singular, quasi-linear experience for all characters persists to this day. As much as I enjoyed the game prior to the first expansion, once the Eternal Empire expansions came out and they established a time-jump along with scattering all the class-exclusive companions to the four winds for any character to encounter, I felt like whatever spark had drawn me in had been lost. My character didn't feel unique, with unique adventures, experiences or choices - I was on the same journey as everyone else.

It's still a fine game, and what made it so special in the beginning still remains. You can still play each of the unique class storylines until they converge - you can even change what class you are mechanically in order to experience a different classes' narrative through a system called Combat Styles (essentially: 'I want to play a character with Sith Inquisitor abilities, but check out the Sith Warrior class storyline/companions') which is really cool! They've also introduced the means to customise your companions to be any role, so previously DPS-exclusive companions can now be Tanks, or Healers. It encourages you to bring the companion you like the most, or the one who's narrative you want to explore at that time, without giving up any synergy with your own character's chosen playstyle. All in all, a fantastic game if you're a Star Wars or KOTOR fan all the same - just go into post Act-3 content with the proper expectations.

Oh - and when it went Free to Play, EA nickel-and-dimed it to death with a massive amount of focus on squeezing money out of everything, with things as simple as the ability to hide your head slot item being put behind a paywall. Incredibly egregious and greedy. As the game has transitioned to being put on maintenance mode this mentality has eased up *a little* (presumably to attract more players who don't wish to pay actual money to play) but between that and the Cartel Store pushing every kind of feature/race unlock/cosmetic under the sun exclusively for premium currency it really does feel like they've stripped the F2P model of all it's flesh and are selling it back to you by the pound. Urgh.

Nostalgia aside, I have to give the game a thumbs down because I remembered who owns EA now. And all the monetisation, obviously, but mostly the first thing.

I am a long standing Player of the Star Wars Old Republic since 2013 and this is my honest review. 

The Base Game , Shadows of Revan , Rise of the Hutt Cartel and the Fallen Empire offered great content especially the Base Game, which is far better than any MMO, however developed by the Old Bioware which cared for the game.

Sadly this is no longer the case. Broadsword Entertainment had been akin to a Parasite, leeching upon it's fanbase. The most updates this game has recieved since 2019 has been shop updates, absurd bundles and further monetization with very little offered content. 

In fact, the content they've developed is credited to Skyrim Esque Radiant Quests. The ever buggy and stupid Dynamic Encounters, which have no story, no voice acting and feel pretty disconnected from the Base Game setting. It's in fact, the worse content to do in the game. 

Ever since Zakuul, Onderon, we haven't seen a properly developed planet. Every content added by Broadsword Entertainment has been lackluster. Progressed by through Daily areas or Flashpoints. No new planets, no new side content and no New Planetary Missions. 

Since Broadsword took over, they've argubly made the game worse. Ranging from new unfixed bugs to poor content, considerable shop updates, bundles and a regulary updated Cartel Market, this game now resembles as a genuine Dress Up Mobile game. 

Overall, it's a good game for new players to run through the Content Bioware Developed over the years, but seeing the stupid anti-consumer practices by a horribly woke , Community Banning, Toxic Developer that's Broadsword Entertainment, I don't see a positive future for this game. It's literally dead, content wise and only milked for profit. 

The only solution for SWTOR to have a future would be without Broadsword Entertainment as it's developer. Shitty Company, Horrific Community Management. They do not listen to feedback, ban people with opposing views. 

For players who want to invest long term into a MMO with active development, good story content and constant updates, I would take a look at other titles on the Market.  Broadsword Entertainment are uncapable of managing expectations.

I'm disappointed by the lack of customer service when dealing with a glitch from their game. I was in a game breaking glitch and was unable to request assistance due to being a 'free to play' player. My ¢2 of course, YMMV.

The game is fun, but the pure incompetence of the dev team or who ever controls the subscriptions cant answer one email for 11 business days. Even to contact them you need a premium acc. Just stay away.

Up until the conclusion of the base game (prior to the Rise of the Hutt Cartel expansion), this game is outstanding. Each class has a very engaging and enjoyable personalised storyline that allows you to live your respective Star Wars character fantasy, with tons of old-school Bioware charm. Every quest-giver was a cutscene where you could engage in dialogue and define your character's mentality or attitude! I lost countless hours to this game and it's strong stance on putting narrative first, even moreso than most conventional MMORPGs tend to do.

However, it feels like they were victims of their own success - the model was unsustainable. They couldn't continue intricately crafted and personalised content for each of the classes with each expansion as it developed; it was simply too much work to keep up. So things started becoming 'shared' experiences, where a character (regardless of class) would go through the same main plotline as all the other classes, and you'd have barely any recognition of your previous efforts (because to do so would require personalisation of the content, which they can no longer do without drastically extending the development time between updates).

This ideology of making the universe at large a singular, quasi-linear experience for all characters persists to this day. As much as I enjoyed the game prior to the first expansion, once the Eternal Empire expansions came out and they established a time-jump along with scattering all the class-exclusive companions to the four winds for any character to encounter, I felt like whatever spark had drawn me in had been lost. My character didn't feel unique, with unique adventures, experiences or choices - I was on the same journey as everyone else.

It's still a fine game, and what made it so special in the beginning still remains. You can still play each of the unique class storylines until they converge - you can even change what class you are mechanically in order to experience a different classes' narrative through a system called Combat Styles (essentially: 'I want to play a character with Sith Inquisitor abilities, but check out the Sith Warrior class storyline/companions') which is really cool! They've also introduced the means to customise your companions to be any role, so previously DPS-exclusive companions can now be Tanks, or Healers. It encourages you to bring the companion you like the most, or the one who's narrative you want to explore at that time, without giving up any synergy with your own character's chosen playstyle. All in all, a fantastic game if you're a Star Wars or KOTOR fan all the same - just go into post Act-3 content with the proper expectations.

Oh - and when it went Free to Play, EA nickel-and-dimed it to death with a massive amount of focus on squeezing money out of everything, with things as simple as the ability to hide your head slot item being put behind a paywall. Incredibly egregious and greedy. As the game has transitioned to being put on maintenance mode this mentality has eased up *a little* (presumably to attract more players who don't wish to pay actual money to play) but between that and the Cartel Store pushing every kind of feature/race unlock/cosmetic under the sun exclusively for premium currency it really does feel like they've stripped the F2P model of all it's flesh and are selling it back to you by the pound. Urgh.

Nostalgia aside, I have to give the game a thumbs down because I remembered who owns EA now. And all the monetisation, obviously, but mostly the first thing.

Don't get me wrong, the game as a whole is probably fine.  However there are several things this game does that I find ridiculously annoying.  

1.  The level scaling...IMO one of the best things about mmorpg's is grinding levels to get more powerful.  That is irrelevant here.  You get a ton of xp boosts for free...yeah i get it everyone wants to get to the endgame content faster.  I have never really been able to run around as my true level because the game scales it down.  Essentially the only thing leveling up does is unlock new skills.

2.  The crafting at its base is also probably fine, however, as a ftp or even preferred status just feels like a kick to the face.  You need 1 crafting and 2 gathering professions to make items unless you buy the missing items from the auction house.  F2p and preferred players only get to pick 2 while you need 3. 

3.  Preferred player status gets thrown around on the website like its the holy grail.  Preferred status doesnt do anything for me really,  unlocked expansions from years ago when i first tried the game and still havent made it far enough to reach the first expansion.  

I just cant in good conscience recommend this game for anyone.  I wish years ago i never spent money so i could be a subscriber.  coming back it just feels like a handicap and i cant play a game with handicap coded into the game.

This game has what, around 240 hours of unique class story content that's all fully voiced? I can hardly think of any SP game that tackles this kind of ambition. I think it's incredible.

This game has the potential to be among my favorites, but it just completely butchers the gameplay and balance for someone who mostly plays SP games and want just a modicum of intended challenge. Instead, you have to artificially restrict yourself for this to happen, which I just dislike.

If they ever patch in a hard mode or a difficulty scaling system that can actually present some challenge in the way you play and build your character, I can see myself coming back to it just to enjoy all the different class stories, like a true Star Wars Singleplayer game.

I gave it my all to play this game on steam but the strain on my i9 9900k 2080 super system with 64 gig of ram was just to much. steam had a issue with the game pulling to hard on the system. I later was able to enjoy the game from the official direct site download. I lost hours to trouble shooting the steam version and would not recommend using the steam port to any of my fellow star wars lovers. I love this game but cant in good conscience recommend this port of it to anyone. user be aware
